newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Four-nation group/Fujitsu win $800 mln cable deals.
newsitem.headline: Four-nation group/Fujitsu win $800 mln cable deals.

text.p: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd (SingTel) gave brief details on Thursday of the breakdown of two giant submarine cable contracts worth a total of US$800 million.
A SingTel spokesman said contracts to build a 23,000 km (14,300 miles) stretch of cable from Singapore to Europe via the Middle East and North Africa would be worth US$720 million.
This network would be built by a consortium of KDD-Submarine Cable Systems, a unit of Japan's Kokusai Densin Denwa (KDD), AT&T Submarine Cable Systems Inc, France's Alcatel and Maristel SpA of Italy.
A second stretch from Singapore to Australia, awarded to Japan's Fujitsu, would be worth US$80 million.
The SingTel spokesman said contracts to build a third part of the network, between Singapore and various Asian countries including China and Japan, had not yet been awarded.
Construction of the first two portions of the network were due to begin in the first quarter of 1997.
When completed, the 38,000-km (23,600-mile) network will serve half the world's population and span the globe from the South Pacific to the North Atlantic.
It will be the world's longest and highest capacity submarine cable network.
The SingTel spokesman said the contracts to build the first two sections of the network were awarded at a private ceremony in Singapore on Thursday. He declined to give further details.
SingTel is one of 90 investors in the cable project.
Other members of the consortium include British Telecom, Deutsche Telekom, Indonesia's Indosat, France Telecom, Australia's Telstra and China Telecom.
